Package tic_tac_toe

Class Board

java.lang.Object
tic_tac_toe.Board
public class Board
extends java.lang.Object
Class implementing the 3×3 tic-tac-toe board consisting of the tiles on which the players place their tokens

The coordinate system used in this program is zero-based. Therefore, the upper left tile is referred to as (0,0), the tile below it is (1,0), and the tile beside it is (0,1). For simplicity, the move (x,y) is shorthand for placing a token on the tile (x,y).

The special coordinate (-1,-1) is used to indicate that, as a result of the game having reached its terminal state (that is, a win, loss, or draw), there are no valid tiles left on which a player's token can be placed.

  • Field Summary

    Fields 
    Modifier and Type Field Description
    static char COMPUTER_TOKEN
    Character code to denote that a tile is occupied by the tic-tac-toe-playing agent (also the character code of the tic-tac-toe-playing agent/computer)
    static int DIMENSION
    Length of this board (which is also equal to its width)
    static char EMPTY_TOKEN
    Character code to denote that a tile is unoccupied
    static char HUMAN_TOKEN
    Character code to denote that a tile is occupied by the human player (also the character code of the human player)

  • Constructor Details

    • Board

      public Board()
      Creates a board object consisting of 9 unoccupied tiles arranged into 3 rows and 3 columns

    • Board

      public Board​(java.lang.String initConfig)
      Creates a board object based on a string that represents its initial state (or configuration)

      The string is of the form %%%|%%%|%%%, which is a flattened representation of the board state following row-major order. Each % stands for a tile while | is a mandatory delimiter to separate rows. Note that % can be any of the following characters:

      • * (EMPTY_TOKEN)
      • H (HUMAN_TOKEN)
      • C (COMPUTER_TOKEN)

      For example, a board with only a human token on the center is represented as ***|*H*|***.

      Parameters:
      initConfig - string representation of the initial state (or configuration)

  • Method Details

    • initBoard

      public void initBoard()
      Configures this board to its initial state, that is, 9 unoccupied tiles arranged into 3 rows and 3 columns

    • makeMove

      public void makeMove​(int row, int col, char token)
      Updates the board state to reflect the most recent move given the row- and column-coordinates of the move, and the character code of the pertinent player
      Parameters:
      row - row-coordinate of the player's move
      col - column-coordinate of the player's move
      token - character code of the player making the move

    • isWin

      public boolean isWin​(char token)
      Returns true if a winning configuration is detected given the character code of the pertinent player; false, otherwise

      A winning configuration is defined as in classical tic-tac-toe: a three-in-a-lane (horizontally, vertically, or diagonally).

      Parameters:
      token - character code of the pertinent player
      Returns:
      true if a winning configuration is detected; false, otherwise

    • isWin

      public boolean isWin()
      Returns true if a winning configuration is detected (regardless of which player made the winning move); false, otherwise
      Returns:
      true if a winning configuration is detected; false, otherwise

    • isDraw

      public boolean isDraw()
      Returns true if a drawn configuration is detected; false, otherwise

      Note that, for a configuration to be considered drawn, all 9 tiles must be occupied without the presence of any of three-in-a-lane. Although it is possible to infer that a position is drawn even before all tiles are occupied, these cases are deemed inconclusive in the interest of simplicity.

      Returns:
      true if a drawn configuration is detected; false, otherwise

    • isGameOver

      public boolean isGameOver()
      Returns true if either a winning or drawn configuration is detected (that is, this board is at its terminal state); false, otherwise

      Note that, for a configuration to be considered drawn, all 9 tiles must be occupied without the presence of any of three-in-a-lane. Although it is possible to infer that a position is drawn even before all tiles are occupied, these cases are deemed inconclusive in the interest of simplicity.

      Returns:
      true if either a winning or drawn configuration is detected; false, otherwise

    • isEmpty

      public boolean isEmpty()
      Returns true if all the 9 tiles are unoccupied (that is, this board is at its initial state); false, otherwise
      Returns:
      true if all the 9 tiles are unoccupied; false, otherwise

    • isOccupied

      public boolean isOccupied​(int row, int col)
      Returns true if the specified tile (given the row- and column-coordinates) is occupied; false, otherwise
      Parameters:
      row - row-coordinate of the tile
      col - column-coordinate of the tile
      Returns:
      true of the specified tile is occupied; false, otherwise

    • getPossibleMoves

      public java.util.ArrayList<Coordinates> getPossibleMoves()
      Returns a list of all the possible moves that a player can make given the current board state (or configuration)

      The possible moves are arranged in row-major order; this order dictates the evaluation of moves if the agent employs the minimax algorithm in its decision-making.

      Returns:
      list of all the possible moves that a player can make given the current board state (or configuration)

    • getOccupiedC

      public java.util.ArrayList<Coordinates> getOccupiedC()
      Returns a list of all the tiles currently occupied by the tic-tac-toe-playing agent (computer)
      Returns:
      list of all the tiles currently occupied by the tic-tac-toe-playing agent (computer)

    • getOccupiedH

      public java.util.ArrayList<Coordinates> getOccupiedH()
      Returns a list of all the tiles currently occupied by the human player
      Returns:
      list of all the tiles currently occupied by the human player

    • toString

      public java.lang.String toString()
      Returns a string representation of this board

      The string representation contains the following details in order:

      • Two-dimensional representation of the board
      • Whether the game is won by the human player
      • Whether the game is won by the tic-tac-toe-playing agent (computer)
      • Whether the game is drawn
      • Whether the game has reached its terminal state (game over)
      • List of all the possible moves given the current board state
      Overrides:
      toString in class java.lang.Object
      Returns:
      string representation of this board
